desk_notes.day_1: Welcome, {name}. Prove I didn't make a mistake.
day_2: Regionbladet sold 200 more copies yesterday. Step it up.
The competition ran a strong front page. We need to answer.
Day two. This is where we set the tone. Don't disappoint me.
day_3: Halfway. I need results, not excuses.
Three days in. The board is watching our numbers.
We're at the midpoint, {name}. Show me you belong here.
day_4: One day left after today. Give me something I can be proud of.
Tomorrow is the last day. Today decides if there even IS a tomorrow.
The clock is ticking, {name}. Make today count.
day_5: Last day. Everything rides on this.
Final day. No more second chances after this.
It's the last morning. Give me the front page of your life.
warning: We're behind. Every point counts now.
The numbers don't lie, {name}. We need a strong story today.
I can hear Regionbladet's presses from here. Dig deeper.
danger: I'm already writing your termination letter, {name}. Change my mind.
HR called. They want to know when your desk will be free.
The board is meeting this afternoon, {name}. Guess who's on the agenda.

critical: {name}, you know what happens if this continues.
I can't protect you from the board anymore, {name}.
This paper has survived two world wars. I won't let you kill it.
I've seen interns do better. Think about that.
bad: Not enough, {name}. We're losing readers every day.
My grandmother could sell more papers. And she's been dead twelve years.
Regionbladet's editor just sent me a fruit basket. A FRUIT BASKET, {name}.
Close the gap or I'll close your career.
warning: We're still behind. Regionbladet doesn't rest.
I see effort. I need results.
Not bad. Not good either. Keep pushing.
neutral: Adequate. That's the nicest word I'll use.
You survived another day. Don't celebrate.
good: Hmph. Not bad, {name}. Do it again tomorrow.
Don't let it go to your head. One good day means nothing.
The board will notice this. Good.
great: ...Good work. Don't tell anyone I said that.
Regionbladet's editor won't be sleeping well tonight.
If you keep this up, I might actually learn your name.

gameover_fired.text: Pack your things, {name}. I already called the temp agency.
gameover_fired.name: Gunnar Ek

gameover_survived.barely: You survived the week, {name}. Barely. See you Monday — if I don't find someone better.
gameover_survived.decent: Not bad for a Stockholm kid, {name}. You can stay. For now.
gameover_survived.dominant: Hmm. Maybe I was wrong about you, {name}. *looks away* Maybe.
gameover_survived.name: Gunnar Ek

onboarding.intro: Welcome! It's good to have someone young on the team.
onboarding.rules: Every morning you'll find today's leads on the desk. Pick one — just one — and dig.
onboarding.threat: If we fall fifteen points behind Regionbladet... there's no job left.
onboarding.start: Got it? Good. Get to work.

desk_notes.day_1: You survived Småstad. Don't let that make you comfortable, {name}.
day_2: Fabriksbladet ran three stories yesterday. We ran one. You do the math.
The mill's PR department called to 'welcome' you. That means they're already watching.
Day two. In this town, day two is when the mill decides whether you're a threat or a joke.
day_3: Halfway. Fabriksbladet's lead is growing. I don't tolerate trends like that.
Three days in. The factory owners are reading our paper now. They didn't before you arrived.
Midpoint, {name}. Either you've found something worth printing or you haven't.
day_4: One day left after today. I need something the factory board can't ignore.
Tomorrow's the last edition. What you do today decides what this paper becomes.
The mill's lawyer called. That means we're doing something right. Or something stupid.
day_5: Last day. Make it count. My printer runs whether we sell or not.
Final edition. Fabriksbladet already printed theirs. Ours better be worth reading.
This is it, {name}. After today, either we matter or we don't.
warning: Fabriksbladet is pulling ahead. Their readers trust them because they never challenge anything.
The numbers are slipping, {name}. People here read the paper that flatters the mill.
We're behind. In this town, behind means irrelevant.
danger: The board called. They want to know why we're losing to a mill newsletter.
Fabriksbladet's editor sent flowers to my office. FLOWERS, {name}.
I've started looking at your replacement's résumé. It's better than yours.
default: The mill opens at six. So do we.
There's a story in this town. Find it.
Fabriksbladet prints press releases. We print the truth. Get to work.

critical: This is worse than Fabriksbladet. And they just reprint the mill's memos.
I pulled you from Småstad for this? Gunnar warned me you might not be ready.
The mill's PR team does better journalism than this. Think about that.
{name}, I don't fire people. I just stop pretending they work here.
bad: Not enough. Fabriksbladet didn't even try today and they're still winning.
The factory workers deserve better than this, {name}. So do I.
Bergström is sleeping well tonight. That means we failed.
I've seen more fight in a press release.
warning: Fabriksbladet is still ahead. They don't have to be good — just safe.
Better. But 'better than yesterday' sets a low bar.
I see the effort. I need the results.
The mill noticed us today. That's a start. Just a start.
neutral: Adequate. For Småstad. We're not in Småstad anymore.
You survived another day. The mill noticed. Don't celebrate.
good: Not bad, {name}. The factory floor is reading us. Keep it up.
Bergström's secretary called to complain. That means we did something right.
Good work. My circulation numbers thank you. Don't stop now.
Fabriksbladet can't ignore us today. Good.
great: The mill's lawyer called. We must be doing something right.
This is why I brought you here, {name}. To keep MY paper alive.
Bergström can't sleep tonight. Neither can I. But for different reasons.

gameover_fired.text: You couldn't handle a real town, {name}. Go back to Småstad where it's safe.
gameover_fired.name: Birgit Ståhl

gameover_survived.barely: You survived, {name}. Barely. This town chews up reporters. You got lucky.
gameover_survived.decent: You held your own. The board won't fire me this quarter. Stay sharp.
gameover_survived.dominant: You actually did it. Bergström's sweating. The workers are reading us. *pauses* ...Don't let it go to your head.
gameover_survived.name: Birgit Ståhl

onboarding.intro: So you're the one from Småstad. I heard you impressed Gunnar. That won't impress me.
onboarding.rules: Same as before — leads on the desk, pick one, dig. But this town is different. The mill watches everything.
onboarding.threat: Fall fifteen points behind Fabriksbladet and you're done. I don't do second chances.
onboarding.start: This isn't a small-town paper anymore. Get to work.
